**Stephanie Kramer-Schadt**, Department and Team Lead —  applied ecologist, population and disease dynamics at the landscape scale, passionate about wildlife per se, carnivores in particular, D6 and movement ecology, uses models as tools to communicate management issues.

**Viktoriia Rachuk**, Team Lead —  quantitative ecologist, stability of populations and communities under global change, interested in theory, synthesis, and integration of data with models to assist conservation.

**Dr.Conny Landgraf**, Coordination — organizes us, behavioral ecologist, interested in sensory and acoustic cues of animals.

**Moritz Wenzler**, GIS-Lab — geodata analyst, responsible for the GIS lab, providing geodata and supporting coding.

# Running Projects

<div class='headerbox'><hbox>Theory and Synthesis</hbox></div>

### Stability under global change and across levels of organization

![](img/team-pop-stability.png)

To understand how populations and communities react to global change we study how their stability is affected by disturbances. To this end we model disturbances of different types and intensity and measure several stability metrics.

* [**How do animals respond to climate change?**](proj-pop-stability-1.html)
* [**How does environmental variation affect stability of populations and communities?**](proj-pop-stability-2.html)

People involved: **Dr. Cédric Scherer**, **Guillaume Chero**, **Carys Jones**

### Wildlife disease dynamics: Linking host and pathogen traits

![](img/team-pop-disease.png)

Pathogens are an integral part of biodiversity, influencing population dynamics of their hosts and playing an important functional role in shaping community structure. Here, our aim is to understand the effect that species as ‘mobile pathogen links’ with their different movement types and life-history strategies have on disease distribution, spread, persistence and evolution. 

&ensp;&rarr;&ensp;see also [BioMove Graduate School](https://www.bio-move.org/)

* [**Infections on the move**](proj-pop-disease-1.html)
* [**Pathogen evolution in dynamic landscapes**](proj-pop-disease-2.html)

People involved: **Dr. Cédric Scherer**, **Tobias Kürschner**

<div class='headerbox'><hbox>Applied Ecology</hbox></div>

### Urban wildlife ecology: How do animals respond to novel environments?

![](img/team-pop-urban.png)

Urbanisation poses risks and opportunities for wildlife. We investigate how species cope with these everyday challenges by analysing the spatial factors and species interactions that underlie their distributions along a rural to urban gradient and by making inference on their behavioral plasticity. 

&ensp;&rarr;&ensp;see also [BIBS — rural-urban coupling](https://www.bbib.org/rural-urban-coupling.html)  
&ensp;&rarr;&ensp;see also [WT Impact](https://www.wtimpact.de/)

People involved: **Dr. Aimara Planillo**, **Dr. Julie Louvrier**, **Carolin Scholz**, **Sophia Kimmig**, **Simon Moesch**

* [**Bridging spatial data in community distribution models**](proj-pop-urban-1.html)
* [**Effects of species interactions and human disturbance on community composition in urban areas**](proj-pop-urban-2.html)
* [**Ecology of red foxes (*Vulpes vulpes*) in anthropogenic landscapes**](proj-pop-urban-3.html)  
* [**Human perceptions of urban wildlife**](proj-pop-urban-4.html)

### Wildlife distributions, population dynamics, and conservation

![](img/team-pop-wildlife.png)

Wildlife faces big challenges persisting in human-dominated landscapes. We model their population dynamics, viability and connectivity using individual-based models on a spatially-explicit basis, with the aim of supporting wildlife management and conservation.

People involved: **Dr. Julie Louvrier**, **Dr. Aimara Planillo**, **Joe Premier**, **Ana Patricia Calderon Quinonez**, **Moritz Wenzler**

* [**Jaguar connectivity in Central America**](proj-pop-wildlife-1.html)
* [**Modelling genetic processes to support the conservation management of Eurasian lynx**](proj-pop-wildlife-2.html)
